summary: This is a reply letter filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's attorney, Laura A. Menninger, in support of a motion to stay civil proceedings in the case Jane Doe v. Darren K. Indyke, et al. The letter argues that the civil case should be stayed until the conclusion of Maxwell's parallel criminal trial (United States v. Maxwell), citing substantial overlap of issues, witnesses, and facts, and the undue burden on Maxwell to litigate from detention under COVID-19 restrictions.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in both the referenced civil case and the criminal case (United States v. Maxwell). Her attorney argues that litigating the civil case while she is detained pre-trial under COVID-19 restrictions is an undue burden.

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger
persons.context: Attorney at Haddon, Morgan and Foreman, P.C., representing Ghislaine Maxwell. She authored this reply letter to Judge Debra Freeman arguing for a stay of civil proceedings.

persons.name: Debra Freeman
persons.context: The judge to whom this letter motion is addressed, presiding over the civil case Jane Doe v. Darren K. Indyke, et al.

persons.name: Darren K. Indyke
persons.context: Named defendant in the civil case (Jane Doe v. Darren K. Indyke, et al.), though the letter focuses on co-defendant Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Jane Doe
persons.context: The anonymous plaintiff in the civil case, identified in the letter as one of the three accusers in the criminal indictment against Ghislaine Maxwell. She is seeking tens of millions of dollars.

connections.description: Menninger is the attorney of record representing Maxwell in the civil case, as stated in the letterhead and signature.
Maxwell is the defendant and Jane Doe is the plaintiff in the civil lawsuit, with Doe alleging abuse and seeking damages from Maxwell.
The letter references Epstein's death and the 'Epstein claims program,' contextually linking Maxwell to Epstein's activities and estate.

events.title: Filing of Criminal Indictment against Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: The indictment in United States v. Maxwell, 20 Cr. 330 (AJN), is referenced. The plaintiff (Jane Doe) is identified as one of three accusers in this indictment.

events.title: Filing of Reply in Support of Motion to Stay
events.description: Laura A. Menninger files this reply letter arguing for a stay of civil proceedings until the conclusion of Maxwell's criminal trial.

events.title: Alleged Abuse Period
events.description: The letter references the time period (1994-1999) for which Maxwell would need to review records to defend against the plaintiff's claims of abuse.

events.title: Proposed End of Stay
events.description: The letter suggests the civil case could resume in August 2021, after Maxwell's criminal trial is concluded.

locations: Denver, Colorado 80203 (Law firm Haddon, Morgan and Foreman)
500 Pearl St., New York, NY 10007-1312 (Daniel Patrick Moynihan United States Courthouse)
MDC (Metropolitan Detention Center, Brooklyn, New York - implied location of Maxwell's detention)
keyFacts: The plaintiff, Jane Doe, is identified as one of the three accusers in the criminal indictment against Ghislaine Maxwell (United States v. Maxwell).

Maxwell's attorney argues that litigating the civil case from the MDC under COVID-19 restrictions is severely burdensome, citing an inability to be deposed, review documents, or have reliable phone contact.
The plaintiff has filed a claim for $75 million in the civil case but, according to the letter, has not yet produced documents corroborating her allegations or verified her complaint.
The letter argues for judicial economy, stating the criminal case will resolve the key issues and the plaintiff can pursue financial claims through the separate Epstein claims program during a stay.
The defense contends the plaintiff is trying to exploit Maxwell's custodial status and the death of Jeffrey Epstein to advance her civil claims with little opposition.
